did.physloc: American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, New York, NY
did.unittitle: 1914 - 1918: Records of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee

archdesc.accessrestrict: The collection is open to researchers with the exception of files that are restricted due to the nature of their contents. Restricted files can include legal files, personnel files, case files, and personal medical diagnoses, etc. Please see our Access and Restrictions Policy for further details.
archdesc.processinfo: Arrangement and collection-level description of the 1914 - 1918 Collection was originally produced by Rose Klepfisz in 1964. Marilyn Henry updated the finding aid in 2010 using current descriptive standards and practices, but did not renumber files or modify arrangement.

scopecontent.p: This collection comprises 155 numbered files from the New York Headquarters records of JDC. The material includes chronologies of events, correspondence, cables, reports, minutes and transcripts of meetings and conferences that document the origins, beginning in 1914, of systematic financial aid from American Jewish organizations to imperiled Jews abroad. In August of that year, Henry Morgenthau Sr., then U.S. Ambassador to Turkey, cabled New York philanthropist Jacob Schiff seeking emergency aid for the Jews of Palestine. Subsequently, three relief committees—the American Jewish Relief Committee, the Central Relief Committee, and the People’s Relief Committee—formed the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, popularly known as the “Joint,” to distribute the funds they raised for needy Jews in Eastern Europe and Palestine. The records in this collection depict the accelerated expansion of JDC activities: fund-raising, annual campaign drives, and ongoing efforts to overcome political obstacles and military restrictions that restricted the dispatch of field workers abroad. Also documented is the developing cooperation with governments, foreign Jewish organizations and nonsectarian voluntary agencies so essential for JDC’s work; it enabled JDC to transmit emergency relief funds and individual remittances, and to provide food, clothing, and shelter to endangered Jews in a nonpartisan, nonpolitical manner. Of note in this collection are records of prominent American Jewish leaders and philanthropists, such as Jacob Schiff, Felix Warburg, Louis Marshall, Cyrus Adler, Julius Rosenwald, and Judah Magnes, Genealogists and family researchers may find relevant correspondence, lists, and receipts for transmission of remittances to individuals.

This subcollection treats the functional activities of JDC in this period and documents efforts to provide care and critical relief for the displaced and the vulnerable; to support children and orphans, rabbis, and prisoners of war; to distribute supplies and kosher provisions, and to respond to personal appeals for aid in locating and assisting family members.

The documents in this subcollection detail JDC's efforts to alleviate suffering and rebuild devastated communities during and in the aftermath of World War I. Note that borders shift in the war era, and that the names of localities reflect both recognized political and indigenous Jewish regions.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, reports on needs, persecution, increased JDC activity, disruptions by war.
This subcollection focuses on the composition, structure, leadership, and operations of JDC and JDC committees.

This record group contains materials that document operations abroad, disruptions caused by war, transmission and use of funds to acquire relief supplies, and relations with overseas organizations, including local Jewish “help committees,” through whom JDC channeled funds. In this period, JDC did not maintain its own apparatus in Europe in the form of offices or permanent representatives.

scopecontent.p: [LIMITED MATERIAL FOR 1918] Financial correspondence (English, German) on remittances, receipts, use of funds for refugee relief. Israelitische Allianz report (June 25, 1917; English, German) on use of funds, relief work for 1916-1917. Appeals for aid for destitute rabbis. Report (December 13, 1918) of Juedischer Nationalrat fuer Deutschoesterreich (Jewish National Council for German-Austria).

This record group contains materials that document expanding JDC committee development, assignments, commitments to undertake relief activities and raise funds for impoverished Jews in various locations abroad.
Miscellaneous on Israel Friedlaender's nomination to, withdrawal from American Red Cross commission to Palestine. Miscellaneous on efforts to locate, aid sister Mania in Warsaw.
Miscellaneous regarding credentials, assignments, sentiments of JDC leadership, representatives: Julian Mack, Judah Magnes, Julius Rosenwald. Booklet for Julius Rosenwald tribute (April 14, 1918).

scopecontent.p: Correspondence regarding travel, accreditation, instructions to Max Senior, Boris Bogen, in Holland to arrange, supervise use of American relief funds. Senior-Bogen reports on travel, logistics, local conditions, finances.

Miscellaneous regarding donations, interests of JDC leadership, representatives: Nathan Straus, Cyrus Sulzberger, Felix Warburg, including several Warburg articles. Booklet with transcript of Warburg testimonial dinner (December 22, 1918).
Miscellaneous regarding credentials, assignments, sentiments of JDC leadership, representatives: Leon Sanders, Jacob Schiff, Max Senior.
Invitations, transcript of remarks from reception (December 1917) at home of Henry Morgenthau for Otis Glazebrook, US consul in Jerusalem, for aid to Jews of Palestine.

scopecontent.p: Reports, correspondence, extracts of meeting minutes on origin of efforts to raise relief funds among American Jews to alleviate Jewish suffering in Europe and Palestine. Henry Morgenthau telegram, correspondence, materials on needs of Jewish community in Palestine, including cable (August 27, 1914) from William J. Bryan, U.S. secretary of state, regarding U.S. plans to send relief ship. Miscellaneous on allocations.
Press releases on JDC relief, allocations, fund-raising, communal conditions of Jews abroad. "Open letters" from JDC leadership.
Correspondence on publication of JDC Bulletin, coordination of publicity. [NO COPIES OF BULLETIN IN FILE.]

did.unittitle: JDC Administration, Fund-Raising, Hero Land Bazaar, 1917-1918

scopecontent.p: Materials, financial statement; logistics on general fund-raising campaign ("Hero Land, or over the top with Uncle Sam and his allies").
Random correspondence (English, Yiddish) on contributions.
Correspondence, fund-raising appeals, commitments, statements on funds raised. Miscellaneous on Judah Magnes proposal for record loan to rebuild Jewish homes in Europe.

did.unittitle: JDC Administration, Fund-Raising, National Emergency Conference, 1917

scopecontent.p: Press release, transcript of banquet (April 15, 1917) of National Emergency Conference, intended to invigorate fund-raising.

Materials, including invitation for convening a special assembly (October 28, 1917) of war relief workers for fund-raising campaign. Minutes, transcript, speeches at dinner sponsored by Felix Warburg.
Transcript of speeches of fund-raising rally at Carnegie Hall in New York, December 21, 1916, including financial pledges.

scopecontent.p: General, financial correspondence on payments, receipts on transmission of individual remittances; heavy on names, queries (many handwritten, English, Yiddish) on family members. Miscellaneous on procedures. [MATERIALS IN FILE NOT SORTED CHRONOLOGICALLY]

did.unittitle: JDC Administration, Financial, Transmission of Relief Funds, January-August 1917

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, receipts on transmission of relief funds, primarily with assistance of U.S. government. Extensive materials on arrangements for transmissions from other nations, especially under war-time conditions, inability to deal with "enemy nationals."

scopecontent.p: General, financial correspondence on payments, receipts on transmission of individual remittances; heavy on names, queries (many handwritten, English, Yiddish) on family members. Miscellaneous on procedures. [MATERIALS IN FILE NOT SORTED CHRONOLOGICALLY]

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, receipts on transmission of relief funds, logistics for transmission due to Trading With the Enemy Act.

did.unittitle: JDC Administration, Financial, Transmission of Relief Funds, April-July 1918

did.unittitle: JDC Administration, Financial, Transmission of Relief Funds, August-December 1918

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, licenses regarding transmission of relief funds; license applications reveal plans, operations of relief projects. Miscellaneous on logistics for transmission of funds, currency exchange.

did.unittitle: JDC Administration, Financial, Transmission Bureau, General and Individual Remittances, 1915-1918

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, instructions on procedures for transmission of individual remittances; forms, including affidavits. Affidavits for transmission of individual remittances (these are standardized). Correspondence on payments, receipts on transmission of individual remittances; heavy on names, queries (many handwritten, English, Yiddish) on family members. Miscellaneous on licenses to send individual remittances and licenses to aid people who may be "enemy aliens." Press notice (November 27, 1916) on Transmission Bureau. Occasional announcements about ability to transmit funds to various countries; instructions to relief societies. Financial reports on operations of Transmission Bureau, by country of destination. Miscellaneous newspaper accounts. [MATERIALS IN FILE NOT SORTED CHRONOLOGICALLY]

did.unittitle: JDC Administration, Financial, Transmission Bureau, Petrograd, Individual Remittances, June-December 1916

scopecontent.p: General, financial correspondence on payments, receipts on transmission of individual remittances; heavy on names, queries (many handwritten, English, Yiddish) on family members. Miscellaneous on procedures when individual cannot be located or has died. [MATERIALS IN FILE NOT SORTED CHRONOLOGICALLY]

scopecontent.p: General, financial correspondence on payments, receipts on transmission of individual remittances; heavy on names, queries (many handwritten, English, Yiddish) on family members. Miscellaneous on procedures. [MATERIALS IN FILE NOT SORTED CHRONOLOGICALLY]

did.unittitle: JDC Administration, Financial, Transmission of Relief Funds, 1914-1916

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, forms on transmission of relief funds, primarily with assistance of U.S. government.
Financial statements, treasurer's and auditor's reports, correspondence on allocations (for relief supplies, or direct remittances to recipient institutions).

This subcollection deals with JDC’s relationship and cooperation with the United States Government, its departments, agencies, and consular officials; with foreign governments and their embassies and consuls; and with JDC constituent member organizations and other private Jewish and non-sectarian humanitarian organizations and agencies to aid in the transfer and distribution of relief funds.

A.J. Sackletter on anti-Semitism in Russia, despite Jewish patriotism, Bolshevism; recommends American Jews have special relief fund for Russia, not limited to Jews.
